bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, October 2, 1940

div1.p: Kean compares the two methods of testing for yellow fever: mosquito bites and sleeping in the infected bedding. He claims that at the time of the experiments, the latter was considered more dangerous.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, October 2, 1940
div1.opener:
2804 N STREET. N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Oct. 2nd 1940
My dear Dr. Hench
div1.p:
Your letter of yesterday
made wonderful time and I am
replying promptly - and by the air
also. I entirely agree with you
that Dr. Cooke is quite on the same
plane as the mosquito men.
At the time that these men volun-
teered every doctor in Havana
and in the United States would
have said that the infected bed-
ding squard ran the greater dan-
ger, as infection by fomites was
universally accepted as a means

of transmission while mosquito
transmission was “a discredited theory”.
In addition the wearing of dead
men's garments and sleeping
in sheets soiled with black vomit
and excreta made it, as Reed
said of it, “a trying ordeal”.
I think I would have chosen
the mosquito every time before
the Finlay theory had been
demonstrated. Gorgas did not
stop the disinfection of clothing
until August 1901, so difficult
was it for the yellow fever experts
to whole heartedly accept Reed's
demonstration of the innocuousness
of fomites - though he had heard
Reed read his conclusions to the
Pan American Medical Congress in
Havana on February 4th of 1901.

Your telegram gave me great
pleasure in making me feel that
I was giving you assistance in
your important and difficult
task. I hope that you have re-
ceived Gen. Truby's article.
